metadata.title: The burden and clinical manifestation of hospitalized influenza among different pediatric age-groups in the tropics

abstract.original_text: In tropical Singapore, influenza occurs all year-round. This study of influenza-confirmed hospitalized pediatric patients compared clinical characteristics and complications by age-group and differences between influenza A and B.

sentences.segment_text: In tropical Singapore , influenza occurs all year-round .
This study of influenza-confirmed hospitalized pediatric patients compared clinical characteristics and complications by age-group and differences between influenza A and B.

abstract.original_text: Methods: This was a retrospective study of pediatric inpatients from January 2013 to December 2014. Patients were grouped into: <6 months, 6 months to <5 years, 5-to <10-year and ≥10 years. Complications were classified into neurologic, pulmonary, and other. We also calculated the incidence of hospitalized influenza cases per 100 000 age-related population.

sentences.segment_text: Methods : This was a retrospective study of pediatric inpatients from January 2013 to December 2014 .
Patients were grouped into : < 6 months ,
6 months to < 5 years ,
5-to < 10-year and ≥ 10 years .
Complications were classified into neurologic , pulmonary , and other .
We also calculated the incidence of hospitalized influenza cases per 100 000 age-related population .

abstract.original_text: Results: There were a total of 1272 patients with a median age of 37 months. The highest hospitalization rates were in the <6 months age-group. Majority (75.2%) had no comorbidity; 25.6% had complications: neurologic 11.9%, pulmonary 9.6%, other 4.1%. Patients with other complications were older, male, and had the highest influenza B rates and the longest length of stay. Influenza A comprised 76.9% of cases and had higher complication rates especially neurologic, compared to influenza B.
